http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

Bamfield was a critical gateway during the telegraph era, a site where international signals punctured Canada and threaded it to other territories around the world. Yet this station was considered one of the most remote places in the Pacific Cable Board’s network due to the difficulties of regional transport. The nearby inlet was known as the “graveyard of the Pacific” for its numerous wrecks; the coastal Telegraph Trail served as a lifeline for their survivors. One cableman recollects that even though it was only one hundred and twenty miles to Victoria, the largest city on Vancouver Island, “you might as well have been a thousand miles away for all the difficulties in transportation.” The town had no road access until 1963 and in order to visit, you have to drive hours along narrow gravel logging roads, avoiding trucks that barrel down without warning and stir up clouds of dust in their wake. Arriving in the small town, which consists of a motel, a bar, and a handful of stores, you see young people strolling along the streets, divers suiting up, and trucks fitted out for recreational camping. Bamfield would not be a destination for so many visitors if it were not for the establishment of a marine science center, which transformed the abandoned cable station into labs and classrooms.

Fanning Island was linked via the Pacific Cable Board's telegraph cable in 1902. It was the most geographically remote station on the line, and cable men often dreaded moving there. Ernest Shackelton, famed Antarctic explorer, once wrote a poem about Fanning Island, a “lonely islet” on which Pacific Cable Board’s communications depended:

“Surf-bound, lonely islet,
Set in a summer sea,
Work of a tiny insect
A lesson I learn from Thee—
For to your foam-white shores
The deep sea cables come;
Through slippery ooze, by feathery palm
Flies by the busy hum
Of Nations linked together,
The young with the older lands,
A moment’s space, and the Northern tale
Is placed in Southern hands—”

On Fanning Island, the relationship of dependency (islands typically depend on mainlands) is inverted: the island was integral part of a chain leading to and supporting the British Empire.

You come ashore via a British cable, laid in 1902 to connect colonial holdings across the Pacific. This link brought with it not only colonial commands, but external business investment, especially in Fiji's growing agriculture industry. Such development made Fiji a well-liked hub by transiting cable men, who wrote about the station's short working hours, annual balls held by local sports clubs, and picnic trips up the river. By the mid-twentieth century, Fiji was a hub for the South Pacific, the only island with redundant routes both to the north and south. Fiji not only depended on these signal flows, but major Western powers depended on the cablemen's smooth operation.

There are only a few ways to get ashore at Norfolk Island. Rough sees batter the island’s high, rocky walls. There are no harbors or ports. Strong currents make entry difficult at the one feasible cable landing site, Anson Bay, and even here landslides can take out the hillside. Despite these difficulties, the island was determined to be the only feasible geographic location to land the first transpacific cable after it snaked down from Fiji and before it branched off to Australia and New Zealand. Norfolk’s inaccessibility had once made it an ideal location for a convict settlement, yet this had been closed almost fifty years prior to the cable’s arrival. Migrants from Pitcairn, the descendants of the Bounty mutineers, have taken up residence in the penal buildings. The island’s insularity coupled with a lack of traffic produced a set of unique connections. For a period of time, the cableman on night duty in Southport would send newspaper extracts to Norfolk Island, where they were typed up by the operator and “tacked up on a tree at the crossroads for all to read.” This news source was known as the “Tree of Knowledge.” By the 1920s, with the development of automatic relays, far fewer staff were needed on Norfolk.

The first transpacific cable was terminated in Australia in the small beach town south of Brisbane, Southport. In 1901, right before the transpacific link landed, its population was only 1230 people. From Southport, traffic was then routed by land to Sydney, but this terrestrial connection was the least stable segment of the entire transpacific cable. Aboriginal inhabitants regularly cut down the line. It was operated until July 1962, when the Southport cable station closed. Today, a park, a street, and an apartment building are named after the cable. In the 1980s, the cable buildings were under threat of demolition. Residents spearheaded a campaign to save them, and they were renovated, restored, and moved to become the Music Department of the nearby Southport School.

In the 19th century, the first undersea network extended around the globe. The British pioneered this effort, drawing upon their technical expertise and naval resources. Many of these early systems followed colonial transportation and trade routes.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies that the associated page is a cable.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Across history, there have been three kinds of cable technology: copper telegraph cables, coaxial telephone cables, and fiber-optic internet cables. To create a page for a new cable, see the reference page for cables.

Heading inland to the Makaha cable station, you surface in a parking lot, in a manhole barely visible under the dirt. Along the beaches to the south of this town reside hundreds of houseless people. O‘ahu’s west shore is home to one of the state’s largest native communities and largest homeless population. In Makaha alone, 32% of its residents live in poverty. Yet, the west shore is also a transit point for a large percentage of the state’s international signal traffic. Since the 1960s, almost all of the island’s coaxial and fiber-optic cables have terminated at three cable stations along this short 30-kilometer stretch. The seemingly divergent histories of telecommunications success and economic deprivation in the area are intertwined, linked to the area's long-standing military occupation. Weapons testing sites and military installations, such as the Lualualei Naval Reservation and the Schofield Barracks, displaced residents from the west shore’s inland valleys. At the same time, the U.S. military was once one of the biggest customers of the cable networks, giving them both an economic boost and a layer of protection when they were set up during the Cold War.

Landing on Midway, you glide up a soft white sandy beach to green grasses. Before 1903, the island was completely desolate, with little vegetation. When the Commercial Pacific Cable Company established the Midway cable station, the high winds and blinding glare of the white sand meant that cablemen had to wear goggles when they went outside. Shiploads of soil were brought in from Hawai‘i so that they could plant grass. The cable company imported chickens, cows, trees, and other plant life to make the area shady and sustainable. The cablemen recount that they found the Island “bare and have made it beautiful.” Life on Midway was quiet and lonely for the twenty-four men stationed there, over 1300 miles away from the nearest inhabited island, but they took pride in their tropical home. They issued “A Weekly Newspaper Published Every Now and Then.” One article records an “exciting day” on which a ship passed nearby the island, but “it is hardly necessary to add, did not stop." After the Second World War, and the infamous battle that occurred here, Midway continued to be a key node in cable networks, first as a stopping point for the first transpacific telephone cable and later as a cable listening post for the U.S. Navy's Sound Surveillance System.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “The Transformation of Midway Island,” The Zodiac: The Journal of the Submarine Cable Service XI, no. 129 (April 1919): 230.
“The Gooney Clarion,” The Zodiac 6, no. 61-72 (June 1912- May 1913).

“Midway Island,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 7, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/Midway/.
Wikipedia contributors, “Midway Atoll,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 7, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midway_Atoll.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A mere twelve feet above sea level, this string of three islands is the only evidence of a massive volcano that lies beneath. Wake, Pearle, and Wilkes Island wrap around a shallow, vibrant blue lagoon, the volcano's empty crater. Dangers are hidden on the atoll's shores, in the military installations from which the United States coordinates another kind of aerial explosion: military missile testing. Were it not for undersea cables, this island might never have become a United States possession. It was discovered in 1568 by Spanish explorers, but was dubbed a “low barren island.” In 1899, the US government annexed Wake Island with the hope of landing a cable there, but given the lack of fresh water and its unhospitable conditions, a station was never built. It was not until after the historic battle on Wake Island during World War II that it finally became a cable node. In 1964, the United States and Japan coordinated to land the first transpacific telephone cable here. Although all systems skipped over the island, Wake continues to serve a strategic function. Hydroacoustic arrays extend out to the seafloor, monitoring for underwater nuclear activity in the Western Pacific.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “Wake Island,” About.com Geography, accessed June 7, 2013,  http://geography.about.com/library/cia/blcwake.htm.
“Wake Atoll,” U.S. Department of the Interior, Office of Insular Affairs, accessed June 7, 2013, http://www.doi.gov/oia/islands/wakeatoll.cfm.

“HA11, Wake Island, United States Territory,” CTBTO Preparatory Commission, accessed July 7, 2013, http://www.ctbto.org/verification-regime/featured-stations/types/hydroacoustic/ha11-wake-islandunited-states-territory/.

Dirk van Oudenol, “CS Restorer,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 7, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cableships/Restorer/1901.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Tanguisson Beach station, built to house American networks during the Cold War era, resembles an underground bunker. Entering, you descend several stories down a fortified stairwell and even then, can only access the equipment room once admitted through a secure metal door. Immediately inside the entrance is a decontamination chamber, a former precaution for nuclear attack, and now a storage closet. Everything inside is redundant in case the domestic infrastructure fails. Multiple, completely separated generators comprise backups for building power and air-conditioning units. Independent battery plants sustain the equipment. During the coaxial era, Tanguisson was staffed by at least two employees at all times, but was often occupied by many more. On the wall, you witness evidence of the community formed here: yearbook-style photos of all of the AT&T stations in the Pacific: Makaha, Keawa‘ula, Bandon, San Luis Obispo, and Manchester. Each has an image of the station, and photos of the people who worked there, with their name and position listed underneath, grouped as a school class would be. Photographs of the cable ships, AT&T cable landings, and maps of Guam decorate the walls. Due to the massive downsizings that have occurred since the 1980s, far fewer people work at Tanguisson today. The cable community, however, still exists.

Ninomiya was the first landing site for trans-Pacific coaxial cables in Japan, built in 1964 to receive TPC-1 from Guam. Unlike many modern stations, it is located in a central residential area populated by commuters to Odawara and Tokyo-Yokohama. Even though Ninomiya is linked to these urban areas, the greenery of Azumayama Park makes them easy to leave behind. Climb up the hill behind the station and you will enter the park, passing several shrines and temples on your journey to the summit. Dense woods open onto a grassy plain with commanding views of Sagami Bay and Mount Fuji. Artist Hokusai Katsushika included this vista in his series of woodblock prints of Fuji as seen from different Japanese towns, drawing Ninomiya into an early-nineteenth-century visual network.

Completed in 1964, Trans-Pacific Cable 1 was the first coaxial cable to link Japan and the U.S. via landing sites in Guam and Hawaii. It was also part of a global communications network that linked tracking stations, command centers, and other infrastructure during the Apollo missions, including the moon landing in 1969. TPC-1 carried voice signals across the ocean for twenty-six years and, since 1990, the decommissioned cable has been used to study earthquakes.
Hawaiian Telecom, formerly the Hawaiian Telephone Company, has long been an investor and owner of US-Hawaiian systems, and has helped to bridge the United States to Asia.

KDD was the incumbent Japanese telecommunications company in the coaxial period. They were the owners of all international projects that landed in Japan, and any country that wanted to interconnect would have to negotiate with them. The company introduced new coaxial cable technologies, invented a new method of burying cables, and built their own cable ship.

The Southern Cross Cable Network was designed as an Internet-based cable that, at the time, would be the fastest and most straightforward route from Australia and New Zealand to the United States. Just as Southern Cross was being put in the water, the cable market collapsed – this was brought on by a combination of the excess capacity offered by the numerous cable systems laid in the late 1990s. The timing of Southern Cross was “perfect,” as its builders recollect, poised on the crest of the cable boom: if they'd started a little bit later, it likely wouldn't have happened.

At the turn of the twenty-first century, three cables came ashore on the rural coast of western Oregon. While systems of the coaxial period usually terminated close to shore, these lines wind inland for over seventy miles, through the fir-populated mountains of the Tillamook State Forest to a Portland suburb nestled in the heart of “Silicon Forest.” The area was first granted this nickname in 1981, only a few years after Intel established a research campus there. Yet the seeds of Silicon Forest were planted much earlier. In the 1930s, the U.S. Forest Service Radio Lab was created in Portland, and developed wireless technologies to track fires as they spread through the forest, including the one that now borders the cable route. Engineers at the Radio Lab eventually developed two of Portland’s most well-known technology companies, setting the stage for today’s high-tech boom. Hillsboro, Oregon is now the home to many computer researchers, chip manufacturers, and cable stations, as well as a budding hub of data center activity. Companies are drawn to Silicon Forest because of its “welcoming” environment: not only do companies get massive tax breaks they in Hillsboro’s E-Commerce zone, but they have immediate access to cheap hydroelectric power from the nearby Columbia River.

Electric Beach, on O‘ahu’s west shore, is named for the large power plant towering behind it and known for regular car burglaries. Three men casually fish off the edge of the point. Families barbeque. A manhole is covered in rusty red dirt. Moving under this manhole, through the cable, and out to the ocean, you briefly pass a small cave with hanging clothes, stockpiled chairs, and collected water. The same beach that makes possible the landing of communications cables – infrastructures that accelerate the movement of information across the oceans – is also a temporary dwelling for some of the least mobile Hawaiians. The Kahe Point station, constructed just north of Electric Beach, has managed to stay out of view, and therefore out of local politics.

Walking around this cable landing, you take care not to fall in the ditches carved into the landscape. Trash clutters the cable landing area, and nearby, shots are fired at the end of Rifle Range Road. The station at Vatuwaqa, like so many others, was built in a largely industrial, suburban area just north of a major city, Suva. Yet unlike many cable stations, it is a place where people as well as signals come together. Men who work for Fiji's international telecommunications company are hanging out around the station. A dog lazily watches the front gate. Inside is a room constructed specifically for teleconferencing. Visiting, you find a sense of camaraderie and hospitality among the cable workers -- this is a place for meeting. In the courtyard, a monument commemorates the site's development as a satellite earth station, the landing point of the ANZCAN cable, and later, the Southern Cross system.

Arriving from the Southern Cross Cable Network, you surface on Narrabeen Beach, unhindered by fishing nets, boat anchors, or dredging equipment. These activities are prohibited in this government-sanctioned cable protection area, one of two established in Sydney in 2005. Once ashore, you travel four miles south to Brookvale, which has been a commercial and industrial center in North Sydney since the 1950s. The station blends in with surrounding businesses: sign printers, auto body shops, and several well-known surfboard manufacturers. As dents are repaired and signals enter local networks, many of the boards crafted in Brookvale end up back in the waves off Narrabeen Beach where volunteer lifeguards operate out of local surf clubs. This safe-zone for surfers and cables is the only Australian site mentioned in the 1963 Beach Boys hit “Surfin’ U.S.A.”

Situated in an office park, the Alexandria cable station is just a few hundred feet from the Alexandra Canal, built in the late nineteenth century to provide barge access to South Sydney. By the 1940s, Alexandria had more than five hundred factories producing bricks, wool fabrics, airplane parts, and other goods, as well as a branch of the Standard Telephones and Cables Company. Set up to provide voice links to Britain in the early twentieth century, Standard went on to manufacture underwater cables, including one between Sydney and Vancouver in the 1980s. Despite its proximity to the station, cables don’t surface in the canal, now widely considered the most polluted waterway in Australia. Instead, lines from the Southern Cross system arrive near the historical cable landing at Bondi Beach before heading inland to Alexandria. Here, connections are made to several nearby data centers, drawn to the area by the presence of the cable head.

Wandering on New Zealand’s west coast, you find a coaxial cable extending out from a sand bank, over a small pond of water, and back into the beach before it heads to Sydney. Aquatic creatures have incorporated its eroding armor and still strong copper core into their home. Old cables dating to the telegraph era have surfaced on this beach: the first international link landed over a century ago, in 1912. Cost-cutting during the Depression prompted the cable company to re-locate a second link, formerly in Wellington, here in 1932. From Muriwai cables extend inland over twenty miles to the growing city of Auckland. This terrestrial path is almost as fraught as the surf-beaten shores of Muriwai. In 1952, incorrectly gauging the location of the cable system, a road grader severed the international network for five hours. After this, the cable companies ensured that the network was extensively marked for the local community.

This northern suburb of Auckland, New Zealand, has been an outlet for northward communications for more than a century. In 1912, after a new Chief Post Office was opened in central Auckland, the Pacific Cable Board re-directed their cable from rural Doubtless Bay to Takapuna Beach. The workers from the station came with the cable, and the cable station was set up on in the Post Office, consolidating networks formerly distributed across the land. As the cable continued to function without major disruptions, networks in the following decades were routed through the suburban beach. When the Southern Cross internet cable was set up in 2000, it too landed on the Takapuna shore. In the cable industry, the prevailing logic is to go with the tried and true.

You land in Spencer Beach Park, a gentle, sandy beach in a protected inlet on the northwestern tip of the island of Hawai‘i. The ocean is calm and clear. Snorkelers glide across the surface, peering at the colorful fish who dart through the waters below. Closer to shore, children splash around and wade up to the sand, where their families are picnicking. A bit farther inland, some campers sit at the opening of their tent and watch the ocean. Hawai‘i, “the big island” in the archipelago that makes up the state of Hawai‘i, is more sparsely populated than O’ahu, where the older the Hawaiian cables have landed. While recent cables encountered opposition from locals when they landed in O’ahu, at Spencer Beach there were celebrations upon arrival of a system from Tahiti, featuring traditional Hawaiian dance and song.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.

“Samuel M Spencer Beach Cable Landing Site,” Submarine Cable Networks: the World of Submarine Cable Systems and Networks, http://submarinenetworks.com, accessed July 19, 2013, http://submarinenetworks.com/stations/north-america/usa-hawaii/samuel-m-spencer-beach.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 2001-,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index2001.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value:
You land on a beach on the Central California coast. You're in between two of the first nodes for internet traffic, Stanford University and the University of California Santa Barbara, and two hundred miles from the major internet technology hub in Silicon Valley. This is where the Internet enters the United States via undersea cable.

The landscape is anything but technological. Behind you, an expansive state park wraps around the California coast. It is cold and rainy. Fog covers the ocean, but it deters neither surfers nor the signals transiting invisibly beneath the beach. From here, signals extend outward to Hawai'i, Guam, Japan, and onward to much of Asia. In what direction will you go?

"It's either feast or famine," one cable station technician tells you. The history of the cable industry confirms this: it is littered with booms and busts. Cables are subject to risk and speculation. The most recent cable boom occurred in the late 1990s, alongside the dot com boom. Cable companies put massive amounts of fiber into the ocean. The privitization and deregulation of international telecommunications enabled new players to enter the network.

Fiber optic systems, which encode signals in light and send them down a thread of glass, have been in development since the early 1980s. Given the conservatism of the industry, the first international system was not put in place until 1986. The immense capacity of these systems have made possible the internet as we know it today.

The Southern Cross Cable Network was designed as an Internet-based cable that, at the time, would be the fastest and most straightforward route from Australia and New Zealand to the United States. Just as Southern Cross was being put in the water, the cable market collapsed – this was brought on by a combination of the excess capacity offered by the numerous cable systems laid in the late 1990s. The timing of Southern Cross was “perfect,” as its builders recollect, poised on the crest of the cable boom: if they'd started a little bit later, it likely wouldn't have happened.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: This tag specifies a path that should operate as a ring, with the last page connecting back to the first page

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: To ensure redundancy, some cables are configured in a ring structure. This is an expensive approach to network design, but if any segment breaks, traffic can automatically be routed in the opposite direction. Many rings were proposed and laid during the cable boom of the 1990s.

In 1876 the Eastern Telegraph Company laid a trans-Tasman cable from Botany Bay to Nelson, where they sought to interconnect with economic trade then centralized in New Zealand’s South Island. A recollection of this link, the first to New Zealand, proclaims: “Cut off by 13,000 miles of sea, and six months in time, from their homeland, British colonists living in remote New Zealand in 1876 suddenly found themselves linked with England—of nostalgic memory—by submarine cable. Thirty-six years of isolation was at an end.”

In Australia, cables were brought ashore at Botany Bay, the site where Captain Cook first staked the British Flag in 1770 and where French explorer La Perouse landed in 1788. Although it was ten kilometers south of Sydney, Botany Bay was selected as a cable site in part due to this proximity to nautical traffic and ship landings, which in turn helped to attract military and defense installations. Even after the telegraph station closed for signal traffic, the building continued to serve surrounding publics – emergent circulations continued to leverage the resources of existing nodes. It was used briefly as quarters for Coast Hospital nurses and subsequently as a women’s refuge operated by the Salvation Army. Traffic was eventually redirected to central Sydney, landing at Bondi Beach, where internet traffic continues to enter Australia. The builders of at least one subsequent cable system, however, still toyed with the idea of returning to La Perouse. The old cable station building, now a museum housing the artifacts of transnational communication; a nearby watchtower, originally meant to look out for smugglers; and a monument named for the early French explorer all serve as reminders of the location’s significance in drawing in heterogeneous historical currents.

“The outside world, with its quips and cranks, is shut out, and we are a community unto ourselves,” one cableman writes of New Zealand’s first undersea telegraph station, established in 1876. Relatively isolated from the nearest town, and with few women present, the cablemen of the Wakapuaka station formed a tight-knit family, one built on male comradeship in work and play. They spent their off-hours fishing in the bay, playing tennis at the station’s courts, producing a Saturday night theatrical show, and drinking heavily. They recalled memorable events in their amateur “newspaper,” the Cable Bay Recorder, which took a sometimes satirical spin on station life. By the early 1890s, Cable Bay became a recruitment point and training station for the telegraph company, at times drawing new men in through family contacts. Station life flourished, increasing staff from only 7 to 17, but competition from the Pacific Cable Board in the north and a fire that damaged the station’s architecture, reduced the vibrant station life and ultimately guided the company’s decision to move the landing to Wellington in 1917. Today, recreational travelers to Cable Bay Holiday Park learn about the area's history from the images of station life, memorialized on its walls.

Strung between Hawai'i and California in 1902, and extending onward to Guam, Japan, and the Philippines in the years after, the Commercial Pacific Cable was the first "American" transpacific link. Secretly, however, it was owned in part by the British Eastern Telegraph company, a trade off the cable layers had to give up in order to gain access to lucrative Chinese markets.

Just south of San Francisco's famous cliff house, on Ocean Beach, thousands of people reportedly watched the transpacific cable land here in 1902. San Francisco had been the hub of telegraph on the United States' west coast since the mid nineteenth century. The first Overland Telegraph, establishing communication between San Francisco and New York City, had been completed in 1861. It was not until 1873 that San Diego, Los Angeles, and Santa Barbara were connected via telegraph. From the late nineteenth century through the beginning of the twentieth century, San Francisco remained the exit point for west-bound US telegraph traffic, all of which funneled out via the city.

In 1893, during an autumn stay in Hawai’i, Robert Louis Stevenson wrote an advertisement for the local news paper: “If anyone desire such old-fashioned things as lovely scenery, quiet, pure air, clear sea water, good food, and heavenly sunsets hung out before his eyes over the Pacific and the distant hills of Waianae, I recommend him cordially to the ‘Sans Souci.’” A decade later, much had changed: the Hawaiian islands had been annexed by the United States and a telegraph cable was strung ashore at Sans Souci beach, connecting Hawai’i to Midway Island. With the completion of this link, President Teddy Roosevelt sent a round-the-world telegram congratulating the cable’s projector, Mackay, from his home on Long Island to New York City via the Commerical Pacific Cable’s transoceanic link. The message took only twelve minutes. Little remains of this history at Sans Souci today, the only indication of the cable is a brief mention at the bottom of the menu of a local restaurant.

In the nineteenth century, Guam was under Spanish rule. Sumay emerged a small port village on the island's Apra harbor, a favorite anchoring spot for fishermen and whalers. In 1898, the Americans sailed into the harbor, and took the island with no struggle. Sumay subsequently became a node for circulations through Guam. The United States set up a Marine Corps Aircraft Squadron. Pan American Airways used the area as a landing for its China Clipper, and subsequently built the first hotel on Guam there. The Commercial Pacific Cable Company established their cable station there. These businesses played a large role in the economic prosperity and development of the village, and many villagers worked at the station.

The first cables to land in Manila led a fraught life, as did the city itself. Already a fortified and busy trading center, Spain took possession of Manila in the 16th century and it became an important node for the traffic of goods to the New World. By the late 19th century, the cobblestone streets were busy with shops, businesses, and horse-and-buggies. With this growth there was also great resistance, which disrupted the smoothness of signal traffic. In 1880 a cable was laid to Hong Kong, extending from Manila over land to Bolinao, an arduous process. By the time the cable station finally opened for service in 1887, the Philippine Revolution was in full swing. The link was repeatedly cut by revolutionary forces, and within a year, it was replaced by a submarine cable landing in Manila Bay. Yet even that cable was not safe from strife – the Spanish-American War started in 1898, and it, too, was cut during battle. After the Americans won that war, the ensuing brutal and bloody Philippine – American War left up to 1 million Filipino casualties. Eager to establish themselves after their victory, the Americans laid another cable, connecting Manila to the United States.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: "Over 130 Years: Early Beginnings," Eastern Communications, accessed July 16, 2013, http://www.easterncommunications.com.ph/index.php/early-beginnings/.
Arnaldo Dumindin, "Second Battle of Manila, Feb. 22-23, 1899," Philippine-American War, 1899-1902, accessed July 16, 2013, http://philippineamericanwar.webs.com/secondbattleofmanila.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Laid by the Dutch East Indies Government in 1859, this cable was intended to help connect the Dutch colonies in the region.

A trading post since the second century, the island of Singapore was a hub of exchange for Southeast Asia long before the British settled there in 1819. When the first underwater telegraph cable arrived forty years later, Singapore was a bustling port city, what one nineteenth-century cable survey called “that thriving halfway house between Europe and the East.” Although produced in a factory in London more than six thousand miles away, the Singapore-Muntok cable was insulated with the coagulated sap of trees native to the region. The Malays had used this substance, known as gutta-percha, for generations to make whips and other products. In the 1840s, a Scottish doctor stationed in Singapore took notice of the sap and brought it back to London. Gutta-percha made an ideal electrical insulator and became the material of choice in the cable industry.  By the time gutta-percha-encased wires populated Singapore's waters, demand had all but wiped out the local flora that made its transmissions possible.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Selected sources:
Ken Beauchamp, History of Telegraphy (IEE History of Technology Series). London: The Institution of Engineering and Technology, 2001. 135-8.
Chester G. Hearn, Circuits in the Sea: The Men, the Ships, and the Atlantic Cable. Westport, CT: Praeger Publishers, 2004. 10-11.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Muntok is a young city by Indonesian standards – it was founded in 1732 by an order of the Sultan Palembang Darussalam, and at that time consisted of only seven wooden houses. When the cable landed in 1859, Muntok was still a small town, now comprised of red-roofed houses clustered around a bay. Tall, straight palm trees lined the empty dirt roads. The engineer who installed the cable wrote of Muntok: “All serene. Great trouble with the telegraphists … who sleep on duty, and otherwise keep Siemens constantly in the station.” The little village woke up over the following decades as the Dutch built houses and canals, using the town as a communications node and a site for exporting indigenous goods. Then, as now, the area was rich in tin, and the harvesting, smelting and exporting of the ore put Muntok on the map for colonial trade. The cables have gone, however, and it remains a quiet smelting and mining spot, an offshoot to the larger and more central Palembang.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “1859 Batavia-Singapore Cable,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/Cables/1859Batavia-Singapore/.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Justus van Maurik, “Indrukken van een 'Tòtòk',” accessed July 19, 2013, http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/maur005indr01_01/maur005indr01_01_0021.php.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Weltevreden, Batavia is today’s Sawah Besar, a section of Jakarta, Indonesia. The area was built up and named by the Dutch East India Company in the 17th and 18th centuries. In the 19th Century it became a full-fledged Dutch colony and in 1859 a telegraph cable was laid here connecting to Hong Kong. Had you arrived at that time, you would have found an established colonial city with a busy port. The area closer to the water held warehouses and offices of many trading companies. Weltevreden was more stately, with shops and government offices. Writings from that period describe the cable station as “one of the favourite stations in the Extension Co.” – it had a rambling garden, tennis courts, stables, a reading room, and a broad entryway flanked by palm trees. Today the area still bears traces of the earlier colonial period. The central square, laid out by the Dutch in the 19th century, displays symmetrical paths and gardens lined with palm trees, which lead to a statue celebrating Indonesia’s independence. In the same neighborhood, a large cathedral sits nearby a temple that is home to both Buddhist and Hindu practitioners, built in Dutch Colonial style.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, "Cable Timeline: 1845-1900," History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 29, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
“Batavia: The Exiles' Mess,” The Zodiac, 1922. Held in the Cable & Wireless Archives.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Trans-Pacific Cable 5 was one of the first ring systems in the Pacific. It has two branches between Japan and the U.S., a direct northern route and a southern crossing via Hawaii and Guam, where it interconnects with other global networks. More than 70 telecom companies from over 40 countries were involved in its construction, and two-thirds of its capacity was reserved before it entered service in the mid-1990s. TPC-5’s southern line carried high-definition television broadcasts for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta.

Long before Bandon became AT&T’s outpost in rural Oregon, it was a critical node in an undersea cable network: the U.S. military’s Sound Surveillance System (SOSUS). From the Pacific coast, SOSUS connected hydrophones and picked up sonic traces of subaquatic movements, from the deployment of Soviet submarines to migrations of whales. Officers stationed at Naval Facility Coos Head tuned into these underwater listening posts and collected data on enemy operations. The Coos Head facility, first opened in 1958, was closed twenty-nine years later in 1987. Improvements in signal-processing had replaced manpower with computers, and as the Cold War wound down the number of Naval Facilities was reduced. Given AT&T’s tight ties with the U.S. Navy, and their assistance in developing SOSUS, it was unsurprising when nine years later, they chose Bandon as a landing point for their newest transpacific cable system, TPC-5.

Central California has been a cable hub since 1964, when a telephone cable to Hawai'i was routed through Morro Bay. The first station in the area was constructed by AT&T, and its location midway between San Francisco and Los Angeles placed it out of the way of potential nuclear attack. 

Although the state has been a hub in communication technology, it has also played an important role in the growth of the environmental movement, pioneered breakthroughs in environmental policy, and is committed to the preservation of wilderness areas. Daniel Press articulates the apparent contradiction: “at the vanguard of paradoxical trends, California is one of the fastest growing states in the country, but is the most ambivalent about change.” Today there are increasing conflicts between these two forces.

In 1962, the balance of undersea cable power was shifting from British companies to the United States. The Keawa‘ula cable station had just been built on O‘ahu’s west shore to land the Commonwealth Pacific Cable. British transoceanic lines no longer stopped at Fanning Island, but rely on the United States. As such, its construction followed U.S. military specifications: it was located underground in a nuclear fallout shelter with walls that were feet thick. Arriving at this station today, you see an elegant set of steps up leading up to a front wall comprised of square glass blocks. One transmission engineer describes Keawa‘ula as a “palace.” Designed by a local Honolulu-based firm, the station's aboveground expansion was inspired by a visit from the CEO of Teleglobe Canada in the 1980s. With little space for gathering inside, the staff members at the time held their meeting in a small and cramped lunch room. Afterward, the CEO saw the station workers outside, joking around and hanging out in the trees like monkeys. In part inspired by the cable community, Teleglobe built a new, staff-friendly environment. The re-designed station grounded the communication hub in the heart of the cable family, yet left intact its Cold War foundations.

Tourists step on a long cable conduit without looking twice, intent on getting to the ruins of an Japanese antiaircraft gun constructed during World War II at the far end of Gun Beach. Guam held strategic military value in part due to its position as a cable hub. At the other end of the beach is the Hotel Nikko, one of the early Japanese five star hotels in the area, a structure dependent on the island’s advanced communications  infrastructure. Undersea cables, shuttling signals to the United States, Australia, and Japan, bisect a material remnant of the Japanese wartime attack and one of the largest indications of Japanese development on the island, two sites with which undersea cables are intertwined. The cable conduits themselves are worn down and blend in with the rocks on the beach. In the water their surfaces are smooth, but rippled, like the ocean. In them, you can see traces of the atmospheric and geological currents that have long positioned the island as central to transpacific movement. Tumon Bay is a node in the cable network, a point of interconnection and redistribution, not simply of electronic signals, but of cultural and political currents.

From a mostly undeveloped beach several miles north of Miyazaki, you follow a dirt path inland until it opens onto a single-lane road. In the distance, a ringed communications tower is visible above the treetops. Homing in on this beacon, you reach a windowless building surrounded on all sides by a barbed-wire fence. Three majestic palm trees and a plaque bearing the logo of Japanese telecom company KDDI mark the entrance, while farmland and greenhouses occupy the surrounding plots. In 1977, the first telephone cable arrived from Okinawa, where a trans-Pacific link to the U.S. had recently been completed. Optical cables followed in the 1990s, but more recent connections have overlooked Miyazaki in favor of the cluster of hubs along the east coast of Honshu Island.
The expansive Commonwealth Pacific Cable, which stretched across the Pacific from Hawai'i to New Zealand and Australia, was officially opened in 1963.

Port Alberni draws its wealth from the vast forest of British Columbia’s shores. Deep inland, sheltered from the Pacific Ocean by a long, narrow inlet, the town’s early dwellers worked at waterfront mills, stripping the woods around them to make products that circled the globe. By the 1960s, many residents worked for MacMillan Bloedel, one of the world’s largest forestry companies. It not only boosted the region’s economy, but each of its divisions had its own social club, organizing social gatherings of all kinds and structuring local life. Yet in the 1960s and 70s, a new constituency began to oppose the logging of Vancouver Island. Environmentalists called for the protection of nature and the establishment of parks. When first undersea telephone link, COMPAC, arrived in 1963, there was a clash between the Canadian Overseas Telecommunications Service and environmentalists when the company cleared forest for cables connecting to the COMPAC system. The cable was ultimately landed with no problems, the cable coming ashore amidst logs, swerving uphill next to the Alberni Plywood Division.

Bondi Beach is perhaps better known as a world famous surfing locale than as a hotspot for cable landing. Since the early twentieth century, however, Bondi has been the landing point for numerous telegraph, telephone, and fiber-optic cable systems. Located right near the center of Sydney, Bondi offers proximity for cable layers that seek to move in close to downtown markets. The most difficult part for cable companies is getting from the coastal beaches where cables land to Sydney's central cable station. Given the lack of duct space under the streets, this makes it difficult to lay new systems directly into major cities.

During the coaxial years, the British Commonwealth staged a number of globe-spanning projects, including COMPAC, ANZCAN, and SEACOM, to bridge the gaps between Commonwealth countries. Following the routes of the colonial cable systems, these networks were intended to take up where colonization had left off.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/title.value: Vladivostock - Nagasaki - Shanghai - Amoy - Hong Kong

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable system was extended by the Great Northern Telegraph Company in 1871, during a boom period of telegraph building, to connect Russia, Japan, China, and Hong Kong.

Although it started out as a small farm town, Shanghai grew into an important and busy port during the Qing Dynasty. In 1842, after the British defeated the Chinese in the first Opium War, Shanghai became a treaty port, occupied by British forces and open for international trade. Throughout the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th centuries, the city grew rapidly. Tall municipal buildings and three-story stone houses with red roofs lined the wide and busy streets. The ports were congested with naval and trade ships from Britain, France, and Japan. The first telegraph cable arrived in 1871, connecting the city to Singapore and Hong Kong. As the cable was laid up the Yangtze River to Shanghai, men armed with rifles patrolled it to stop sailors from throwing anchor and severing the connection. By 1916, ten more cables - sponsored by a range of governments and militaries - had landed here, linking to Japan, Russia, Yap, the Philippines, and other Chinese ports.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: “CABLE SITUATION AT AMOY. MUCH DISCONTENT” reads the headline in a 1931 Singapore newspaper. “The prosperity of business in Amoy largely depends upon its rapid communications by cable to the South Seas,” the article explains, but telegrams “intended for Amoy are now relayed to Shanghai.” Service was disrupted when, a few days prior, Chinese officials shut down the Great Northern Telegraph Company office on Kulangsu Island, where a Danish cable stopped on its way from Hong Kong and Shanghai. This cable originally bypassed Amoy, but in 1873, the company added a branch to the city without Chinese permission and began profiting from the added traffic. When China took control of the Kulangsu-Amoy connection in 1931, it disrupted local businesses already heavily reliant on submarine telegraphy.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: On AtlanticCable.com, many landings indicated by "Mogi, Nagasaki-ken, Japan"

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Like many port cities in Asia, Nagasaki was “discovered” by imperial powers – in this case, the Portuguese – and developed for trade. In the nineteenth century, Nagasaki became a busy transit point, with a vibrant ship-building industry, an anchorage site for the Japanese navy, and a telegraph cable landing point. Three years after its first submarine telegraph cable was landed in 1871, the telegraph company established a headquarters here, in a large two-story office building abutting the harbor. Within a few years, Japan would build up its internal landlines, and the country would be connected to the rest of the world via Nagasaki. The importance of this station was clear to Japan and its enemies. Described as “clutching the aeortic artery of international communications in Japan,” Nagasaki, as a hub and military harbor, was also a target. The cable to Vladivostok was taken out of service during the Russo-Japanese War, but the city remained undamaged. During World War II, however, Nagasaki was hit with the atomic bomb, the second and last to ever be deployed, killing several hundred thousand people. After the Japanese surrender, the city would slowly rebuild. Old communications lines were taken out of service, and new coaxial cables laid in their place.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 10, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

“The Great Northern Telegraph Company Centenary Book,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 10, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/Books/GNT/.
“Umegasaki Stories,” Nagasaki: People, Places and Scenes of the Nagasaki Foreign Settlement 1859-1941, accessed August 10, 2013, http://www.nfs.nias.ac.jp/page007.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Vladivostok is located at the south-easternmost tip of Russia, on the hills that rise at the head of the Zoltoy Rog Bay. The harbor’s name means “Golden Horn,” and references a similarly shaped harbor in Constantinople. Both cities grew up on the edge of their states and became important ending and beginning points for travel, shipping, and communication. In the early 1870s, when the Great Northern Telegraph Company established a cable landing at this site, the city was a busy trading port with a shipbuilding yard, which welcomed new settlers. Vladivostok’s first street was built in 1871, winding from the bay uphill to the wooden and stone residences that were rapidly appearing throughout the city. That same year the cable arrived, connecting Russia to Nagasaki and on to Shanghai. The telegraph office sat in a stately three-story office building at the corner of two major streets. By the turn of the twentieth-century, Vladivostok had developed into a modern city with tall buildings, shops, and hotels. The Trans-Siberian Railway, built at the same time, terminated in Vladivostok, connecting this easternmost edge of Russia to Moscow. Today, Vladivostok is the largest Russian port on the Pacific Ocean and is a busy city of about 500,000 people. People and goods still ebb and flow through this bay. The Russky Bridge, completed in 2012, is the largest cable-stayed bridge in the world, hovering over the Eastern Bosphorus Strait and connecting Vladivostok to Russky Island.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Wikipedia contributors, “Zolotoy Rog,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 9, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zolotoy_Rog.
Wikipedia contributors, “Timeline of Vladivostok History,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 9, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_Vladivostok_history.
Wikipedia contributors, “Vladivostok,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 9, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladivostok.
Wikipedia contributors, “Russky Bridge,” Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, accessed June 9, 2013, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russky_Bridge.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Japan-U.S. cable network was one of several ring networks laid at the turn of the twenty-first century. It cost over a billion dollars and has connected three landing sites in Japan with two U.S. stations via a direct northern route and a southern route through Hawaii. Owned by a 35-member consortium, the cable has been upgraded to transmit more than 15 times its original capacity.

Kitaibaraki thrived as a center of coal mining in the nineteenth century, with rail lines connecting it to Tokyo a hundred miles away. In 2011, a 9.0-magnitude earthquake devastated the city. The closest cable station to the epicenter, Kitaibaraki was severed from both the U.S. and Asian networks, though Japan’s cable density allowed much of the traffic to be rerouted. The tsunami also wiped out an important cultural landmark: a red pagoda-like meditation retreat designed by Japanese philosopher and art historian Tenshin Okakura. While this structure was rebuilt in its original location on the rocky shores of the Pacific Ocean, cable operator KDDI announced the construction of a new tsunami-resistant station in Chikura that will stand ninety feet above sea level.

To get to California’s oldest still operational cable landing point, established in Point Arena in 1957, you would have to travel over a hundred miles north from San Francisco on narrow wooded roads. The cable station is positioned on a bluff overlooking the Pacific. Across the road from the station, families picnic at a campsite. Cows graze in a nearby pasture. Between the station and the beach, a sign restricts access to a “sensitive habitat area.” At first glance these environments, and the signs indicating environmental preservation, appear to secure both wildlife and cables, protecting infrastructure from perception and potential tampering. But such environments also pose a problem to those laying undersea cables. At this station, cable builders had to undergo extra permitting,  and ultimately delay, to ensure that they did not endanger the Point Arena mountain beaver.

Shima is a major hub with connections to six active international cable networks, but it remains largely invisible to local residents. While cables are hidden, several festivals call attention to the surrounding ocean, known for its abundant marine life since at least the eighth century. Every June, a twenty-foot wooden spiny lobster is paraded through the city streets to encourage a bountiful harvest season. And in September, four men carry an oversized waraji (traditional straw sandal) into the ocean, setting it adrift. This ritual is designed to ward off Dandarabocchi, a mythological giant so large that his footsteps create lakes. Afterwards, spectators gather on the beach for dancing and a fireworks display.

You can journey to the village of Maruyama along cables from the U.S., Australia, or various sites in Southeast Asia. But upon reaching the station, you may feel as if you’ve traveled even farther—and back in time. Across the road is Rosemary Park, a detailed replica of a sixteenth-century English town. Built in 1997 by British architects, the tourist attraction includes a working windmill, formal gardens, a duck pond, and a recreation of Shakespeare’s childhood home, complete with lifelike statues and time-specific furnishings. Shakespeare referenced rosemary in his plays, and Maruyama is known for producing this and other herbs. While the park looks to the past, the modern cable station is one of Japan’s most popular landing sites. Both enact a kind of virtual transit to far-off locales.

The Pacific Cable Board cable was laid in 1902. It had been imagined for decades before it could actually be laid. It was only once the British came to value strategic communications that Sanford Fleming, a Canadian, was able to push the project through.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: 1882-?; Manufactured by Telcon; Laid by Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company; Seine

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 1882 another telegraph line was extended between Singapore, a hub for Asian traffic, and Batavia.

The ASEAN (Association of South East Asian Nations) submarine cable was inaugurated in 1983 by “a three-way conversation among the Communications Ministers of Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand,” reports the New Straits Times. With landing stations in all three countries, the cable had a capacity of 1,680 telephone lines and carried telegraph and telex messages as well. But the inauguration placed the most emphasis on the cable system’s political significance. It represented “the unity, understanding, and cooperation among the five ASEAN nations” and “exemplified their strong dedication to work towards common objectives beneficial to all.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Source: “Three-way Link-up launched,” New Straits Times, 28 September 1983: 2.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Note: unconfirmed that SEACOM landed at Katong; not sure if image matches landing

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Long before it was a cable hub, Katong was a center of private wealth in British Malaya. Colonial elites established giant mansions, coconut plantations, and weekend villas along the waterfront in this East Singapore district beginning in the early nineteenth century. Though some of these structures have been preserved and restored, often painted bright colors, the still-affluent neighborhood has also seen some major physical transformations. The beach where you emerge from the APCN-2 network didn’t even exist before the 1970s. It was created as part of a massive land-reclamation project designed to add more space for housing on the island. Modern apartment towers and Singapore’s largest park now occupy the expanded coastal area. Soon after the artificial beach was completed, a telephone cable arrived from Hong Kong, followed by connections to regional fiber-optic networks in the 1990s and early 2000s.

Popular with surfers and backpackers, the small fishing village of Cherating lies approximately twenty miles north of Kuantan on the central east coast of Malaysia. Every spring and summer, leatherback sea turtles swim through the calm waters and lay their eggs on broad sand beaches lined with Casuarina trees. These same environmental conditions are well suited to underwater cable landings: sand is an accommodating medium for cable burial and there are no strong ocean currents to shift or expose cables once in place. Although cables have connected here since the 1990s, the current station was built as part of Telekom Malaysia’s investment in the APCN-2 system of the early 2000s. A single-story complex with pitched roofs set back from the road and surrounded by a security fence, the Cherating cable station is relatively unassuming. But a large communications tower, visible for miles, marks the site as a hub for signal traffic.

As a landing site for the 1983 ASEAN cable, Songkhla was the first station in Thailand to receive underwater telephone links. Cables surface on the idyllic Ban Kao Seng beach near the country’s largest natural lake, the same place where invading Japanese troops landed at the start of the Second World War. Years earlier, according to local folklore, a wealthy governor from the south of Thailand was sailing up the coast with a fortune in gold when his ship ran aground near Ban Kao Seng. Stranded, the governor ordered his fortune buried, committed suicide, and left instructions for his severed head to be placed on the rocky cliffs above the beach. The name Kao Seng derives from the treasure’s supposed value: 900,000 baht. Some believe it’s still buried there alongside several underwater cables entering the Gulf of Thailand.

Although it was a landing site in the 1997 Asia-Pacific Cable Network, Chao Samran, Phetchaburi never grew into a true cable hub. Later connections favored stations in the south, closer to Malaysia, Singapore, and Indonesia, or the economically dominant Satun across the Gulf of Thailand. A similar shift occurred a hundred years ago during the reign of King Rama VI. In 1918, the king built a royal summer residence on the shores of Phetchaburi province, renamed Hat Chao Samran or “Royal Leisure Beach.” For a few years, Chao Samran was a popular vacation spot among elites. But poor transportation and a lack of fresh water eventually led the king to demolish the residence and rebuild it further south where resources were more plentiful.

The first and last submarine link to connect Infanta was landed in 1990. Known as the “gateway to the Pacific,” this medium-sized port city is located on a tiny peninsula that juts into the Polillo Strait, leading to the Philippine Sea. In the 1990s, the city led a double life as a manufacturing center for the province and a quiet escape destination. Straw-roofed resort huts dot the blue-green waters. The city itself sprawls inward with two-story buildings housing banks, offices, shops, and restaurants. Farther inland, logging sites and salt flats ship their spoils to the town. More recently, the city literally had to dig out from natural disaster: a monsoon in 2004 set off a mudslide in the nearby mountains, burying Infanta in millions of cubic meters of mud, water, cut logs, and uprooted trees. The cable escaped the catastrophe, having gone out of service just a year before.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1951-2000,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 16, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1951.htm.
http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTPHILIPPINES/Resources/ElmerMercadoWBCEACaseStudyInfanta.pdf

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As they are laid and maintained, cables shape contours in the environment, leaving traces of their paths even after they are retrieved. These residual effects then make it more likely that new cables will be laid down existing paths, solidifying and sedimenting the network.

The third link between Hawai'i and the United States was a straightforward engineering project. AT&T needed more transpacific capacity, and as in their previous systems, collaborated with Hawaiian Telecom to build the infrastructure that would meet their needs. As a result, the two companies would then own all of the circuits on the system, blocking out any other telecommunications companies from ownership.

AT&T has been integral to the laying of submarine cables since the 1950s. During the Cold War period, cable laying was "club" affair - only nationally-affiliated telecommunications companies could participate. AT&T facilitated all of the United States' transoceanic projects during this time, and built an number of cable stations on US shores.
This cable was extended between Guam and Japan's Bonin Islands in 1906. It connected the Commercial Pacific Cable's line from the United States all the way to Asia.

On some islands, even finding a shore on which to land one’s cable is a fraught process. Located about 1000 miles south east of Japan, the Bonin Islands have steep coastlines that make landing difficult. Rocky mountainsides rise up from the blue-green sea, gradually turning from stone into lush greenery higher in the sky. In some spots, small strips of sand slice between the ocean and the hills. In the early 1900s, a cable landed on one of these remote beaches, connecting Guam (and thereby the United States) to Japan. The Japanese had claimed the land only a few decades earlier, and about forty settlers made their homes on the previously uninhabited islands. The American company sent British ships and workers here to land the cable, all of whom were tentatively but amicably received. Like the small beaches that marry the water and land, the islands served as the tiny but essential solder point between the US and Japan, mediating communication between these two distant societies.

Dirk van Oudenol, “CS Restorer,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network,” atlantic-cable.com. Accessed July 10, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cableships/Restorer/joint.htm.

Lionel Berners Cholmondeley, M.A., The History of the Bonin Islands: From the Year 1827 to the Year 1976 (London: Constable & Co. Ltd., 1915), accessed July 10, 2013, http://mysite.du.edu/~ttyler/ploughboy/boninchol.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In 2010, the Honotua cable – stretching between Hawai‘i and Tahiti – was made possible by funding from the French Government, granted as part of a wider measure to extend broadband to French citizens and improve the country’s digital economy.

Until recently French Polynesia relied on wireless means of communication, but due to the scarcity of satellites in the South Pacific, the cost for bandwidth remained high for its approximately 270,000 residents. In 2010 the Honotua cable—stretching from Tahiti to Hawai‘i—was made possible by funding from the French government, granted as part of a measure to extend broadband to all French citizens and bridge the digital divide. Honotua was not seen simply as a technical bridge to a global network, but as part of, and emanating from, local language and mythology. Ceremonies were staged at the cable landings, where men and women danced in traditional native attire. The cable was named in Tahitian: hono means a link and tua means the back, backbone, or far ocean. Legend has it that the link traces the route of the Tahitian Queen, who long ago lived at the cable landing site at Papenoo, and had traveled to the landing site at Hawai‘i. The cable company laying the system learned of a second coincidence after the cable had already been named. The local mayor informed them that a man who lived near the landing had a relative named Honotua, yet another connection of cable to local genealogy.
This cable, originally laid by the German-Netherlands Telegraph company, was diverted to Okinawa by the Japanese in 1916.

A century ago, Yap was a Pacific communications hub, the junction point of three cables linking Guam, Shanghai, and Manado. Colonized by Germany, it was a critical node in their vast cable network of over 18,000 miles. From Guam, the United States relied on the German-Netherlands network to connect to Shanghai. Yap formed an important bridge between America and China. During World War I, the Japanese seized the island and Yap became not only a “cable threat,” but a threat to the sea route between the U.S. and the Philippines. After the war, the possession of Yap, its cables, and its coaling station was the subject of a dispute between the United States and Japan. Japan claimed that the island had been designated to her under a Mandate of the League of Nations. The United States sought to put Yap under “International supervision” as an international cable station, rather than under control of a single nation. After a year of deadlock, the United States and Japan came to an agreement that split the network, and subsequently eliminated all cable links. Today, Yap remains without cable systems and without high-speed Internet infrastructure, linked only via wireless technologies. A single satellite station carries all of Yap’s traffic out of the country.
This cable was strung between Pantai Cermin, Medan, Indonesia, and Penang, Malaysia.

Today, Medan is the fourth largest city in Indonesia and the second busiest port. Huge shipping boats slide through the grey water, alongside long dark piers. Here, they are filled with tobacco, palm oil, tea, and rubber, before being sent back out through the Strait of Malacca. While goods flow out, people and signals flow in. The city itself is modernized and notoriously ethnically diverse, its industries requiring fast technologies and drawing a range of immigrant workers. In many ways, it is also a pilgrimage destination. Since 1906, religious devotees have traveled here to visit The Great Mosque of Medan. Today, visitors come from around Asia to feed their tastes as well as their souls: the city is known for its myriad cuisines, from Javanese cuisine, to Batak pork, Chinese noodles, and Indian curries. In 1999, a cable surfaced here connecting from Singapore, through Medan, to Penang. Medan had been an essential node in this path before – in the early 1890s, coincident with the city’s growth as a tobacco exporter, a telegraph cable was laid here connecting to Penang and Acheen. As trade continued and industry grew, so too did the information transiting the city.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 13, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
“Port of Belawan, North Sumatera, Indonesia,” accessed July 13, 2013, http://seaport.homestead.com/files/belawan.html.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Kuala Muda station in Penang, commissioned in the early 1980s by Telekom Malaysia (TM), was the country’s first landing site for underwater telephone cables. As the westernmost point on the Malay Peninsula, the state of Penang made a logical terminus for the Indian Ocean Commonwealth (IOCOM) cable from Chennai, completed in 1981. While Penang’s nineteenth-century telegraph connections surfaced in the bustling heart of colonial George Town, IOCOM and subsequent cables landed ten miles north in a comparably remote area where the Muda River flows into the Malacca Strait. By placing the station on the outskirts, TM minimized the risk of cable damage from anchors and trawls of passing ships. Today, the company controls all four of Malaysia’s cable hubs (and five smaller stations), similarly positioned in fishing villages and beach towns on the urban fringe.
This cable, originally laid by the German-Netherlands Telegraph Company, was diverted by the Japanese to Palau in 1942.

Menado derives from the word manadou or wanazou, meaning “on the far coast” or “in the distance.” The town is located on the far northwestern tip of the Indonesian island North Sulawesi. The Dutch East India Company built a fortress here in 1658 and from that time it was slowly and steadily colonized and Christianized by traders and missionaries. The thick stone walls of the city’s fort still exist, but outside it, the town has grown into a colonial village with hedgerows, streets, gardens, and cottages. In 1905, traveling via Menado’s first undersea cable, you traverse a busy port filled with large trading vessels and smaller, slimmer pinisiq, Indonesian sailboats. The beautiful bay actually makes a bad harbor: the reefs and steep slope in the sea floor make it difficult to anchor. Between the cable landing and the distant mountaintops, expansive coffee plantations have developed. Although it will never grow into a sizeable port city, this location will remain important to the Dutch in part due to its massive coffee exports.

“The Commercial Pacific Cable Company,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed July 19, 2013, http://www.atlantic-cable.com/CableCos/ComPacCable/.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: A second cable was laid by Eastern Extension between La Perouse, Australia and Nelson, New Zealand in 1890, where it would function until 1917, when it was relocated to nearby urban centers in Sydney and Wellington.

Sanford Fleming and the Canadian Government mobilized arguments about security to establish the first transpacific cable system in 1902, creating a foundational route for all north-south Pacific traffic. This system mastered the scale of the globe: the Pacific Cable Board line between Bamfield, Canada and Fanning Island was then the longest undersea cable in the world. This system also required new expenditures for infrastructure and planning. A new 8,000 ton ship, the Colonia, had to be constructed specifically for the line.

Hawaii-1 was the first telephone cable that stretched across the Pacific, linking up California with O'ahu. After 32 years of service it was retired, and it has since been re-purposed for scientific research.

In the 1950s, the first transpacific telephone cable was landed at Hanauma Bay, solidifying Hawai‘i’s as a hub of Pacific communications. The station was buried underground like many Cold War-era infrastructures, disguised as part of the hillside to prevent it from attack. The burying of the station was not its only impact on the environment: installers had to dynamite their way through a reef to ensure the cable had a safe path out to sea. More than fifty years later, this path has become a corridor of environmental tourism. The hole in the reef, now dubbed the “Telephone Cable Channel,” draws scuba divers and snorkelers through one of Hawai‘i’s foremost nature preserves. The cable, once used to traffic telephone calls, has been re-purposed by marine scientists to monitor the undersea environment, sensing aquatic lifeforms and seismic movements of the ocean floor.

In the 1920s, the Pacific Cable Board lay a higher capacity system directly from Suva, Fiji to Auckland, bypassing Norfolk Island. Thus began the era in the South Pacific of skipping over intermediate islands to ensure more "direct" routing.
Eastern Extension's cables between Australia and New Zealand were relocated to Bondi Beach and Titahi Bay, outside of Wellington, in 1917.

In 1917, following a fire at their cable station on New Zealand’s South Island, the Eastern Extension company re-located their links to Titahi Bay, on the North Island. The nature of the company and the culture of the station changed with this move. There was no need to physically man the coastal cable house. Here, the circuits were automatically switched once they came ashore and messages were routed directly to Wellington. Cable work no longer took place in a rural outpost, but the Eastern Extension’s office in the center of the city. On one hand, given the World War unfolding at the time, this shift to a population hub seemed to make the cable more secure. But on the other hand, along with automatic transmission, it drastically changed the culture of tight-knit cable operators.
Completed in 1980 by Japan’s KDDI Corporation, this coaxial cable linked Hamada and Pusan. It was decommissioned in 1997 and donated to the Ocean Research Institute at Tokyo University.

For a relatively brief period between 1980 and 1997, you could travel here from Pusan along a coaxial cable under the Korea Strait. Emerging on a white-sand beach, you’d find one of the largest deep-sea trade ports in western Japan, abuzz with ships carrying local fish, seaweed, and wood products. The town formed around a hilltop castle built in 1620 and later destroyed by its creators to prevent it from falling into enemy hands. Hamada’s cable station was also abandoned and dismantled, but for a different reason: new fiber-optic networks offered faster connections between Japan and Korea via hubs closer to Tokyo-Yokohama. While the castle ruins, including a stone foundation and wooden gateway, are now a popular tourist attraction that reminds visitors of the city’s long history, evidence of its place in the underwater network has all but disappeared.

Busan is a major gateway for East Asian cable traffic, with five submarine networks interconnecting at this station. It is also where some of the best seaweed in South Korea is grown, one cableman tells you. Unfortunately, the boom in South Korean seaweed production, which comprises over half of the country’s aquaculture, doesn’t benefit international signal traffic. Dense seaweed forests immediately off Busan’s shore twist around ropes bordering the cable’s path. Harvesting them, fishermen come close to the country’s international communications lines. When building a new system, cable companies aren’t allowed to dig into the seabed, since this might disturb the fragile seaweed’s growth. Instead they carefully place each cable in a “mattress” before lowering it down into the crop.

Tasman 1 was the second telephone cable laid across the Tasman sea, establishing 640 new circuits between Australia and New Zealand. A state sponsored affair, it was a collaboration of the Australia Overseas Telecommunications Commission and the New Zealand Post Office, and was manufactured by the British company Standard Telephone and Cables Limited. It cost 14.3 million.
The French post and telegraph service extended a system between their island of Poulo Condor, off the coast of French Indochina, and Pontianak in the Dutch East Indies in 1906.

In Malay and Indonesian mythology, the pontianak is a vampiric ghost, the spirit of a woman who dies while pregnant. The town of Pontianak is named after one such woman, said to have haunted the first Sultan who ruled the area. Founded in 1771 on swampy ground near an old coastal trading station, Pontianak is watery, foggy, and not entirely terrestrial. The early settlement became a center of piratical activity as well as a port for the Dutch East Indies Company. In the 19th century the land officially became a protectorate of the Dutch East Indies. As the port grew in size it was built mostly on stilts due to the swampy land. At the turn of the 20th century, it was the French, however, not the Dutch, who laid an undersea cable to the site, connecting to French Indochina. It was not until a century later, in 2006, that the next cable landed here, a fiber-optic one linking out to Batam and Jakarta.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Marco Polo stopped at the remote islands of Poulo Condor (now known as Con Dao) on his way from China to India, later writing “there is nothing about them worth mentioning.” Yet the archipelago’s remoteness and nondescript character made it an ideal setting for more than a century of incarceration. After taking control of Poulo Condor in 1787, the French constructed a 120-cell prison to hold opponents of the colonial government, including many high-ranking Vietnamese military leaders. While prisoners were detained, French signals flowed freely through the island’s telegraph station. The prison was later turned over to the South Vietnamese and became the site of the notorious “tiger cages,” maintained by the U.S. during the Vietnam War. This isolated island became globally visible when a 1970 issue of Life magazine revealed the prison’s inhumane conditions.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: You might have come here in 1871, when the China Submarine Telegraph Cable company surfaced a cable from Singapore. Or, you might have come along the 1884 cable, brought ashore by the Eastern Extension company. Despite these outlets to British Empire, the city remained in the hands of the French, who did not lay their own cable until the turn of the twentieth century. It was the French colony of Cochinchina and as a port, a city, and a communications hub, became militarily, economically, and ideologically important for the following century. Indigenous rebel forces regularly fought bloody battles against colonization, as the French and Japanese squabbled over the city until its independence in 1954. During the Vietnam War, the U.S. and other western nations would back forces originating from Saigon in their fight against communist North Vietnam. Leaving the city during these years, transmission was slow: the government controlled the cable station and any international messages were delayed for at least an hour in order for the censors to approve them before they could be sent through the system.
