http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In the 1920s, the Pacific Cable Board lay a higher capacity system, a "loaded cable" that eventually transmitted 150 words/minute directly from Suva, Fiji to Auckland, bypassing Norfolk Island. Thus began the era in the South Pacific of skipping over intermediate islands to ensure more "direct" routing.
This system, the first link from India to Asia, was extended by the British Indian Extension Telegraph Company in 1870.

On December 31, 1870, Madras, India (the colonial name for the city now known as Chennai) received its first underwater telegraph line, which linked India to Malaysia. The telegraph station in Madras was connected in the other direction to overland lines, controlled by the Indian government, reaching across the subcontinent to Bombay. One of the last British ports to be developed, Madras lacked a proper harbor until 1890. Due to the city’s shallow coastal plain, ships had to offload cargo from nearly a quarter mile out to sea, and only then when waters were calm. When the Telcon cable ship arrived, recounts an Australian crewmember, rafts and surfboats were used to bring the line close to the beach before it was “hauled on shore by natives through the surf which is heavy there.” A successful test of the Madras-Penang connection was celebrated with a dinner on the ship and, later that evening, a New Year’s Eve party at the Madras town hall “to which we were all invited, it was a grand affair.”

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Selected sources:
Jorma Ahvenainen, The Far Eastern Telegraphs: The History of Telegraphic Communication between the Far East, Europe and America before the First World War. Helsinki: Suomalainen Tiedeakatemia, 1981. 19.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Was located at 44 Northam Road, now Jalan Sultan Ahmad Shah.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: In George Town at the turn of the 19th century you witness the beginnings of a modern city. The streets are lined with warehouses and ghauts, wide steps leading from the street to the water. Banks, trading areas, and emporium stores are beginning to appear along Beach Street. Since its founding by the British East India Company in 1786, the town has grown into a bustling trading port and commercial center. George Town has been built on water: its commercial center stands on a swampy wetland that was leveled and filled in the early 1800s. Seeing that this was precarious, English settlers built their bungalows high up on top of Penang Hill, forbidding natives to do the same. The settlers’ wealthy Chinese business partners were allowed to build in the middle part of the hill. The cable – part of the emerging modern city – surfaces close to the water, but ultimately connected those who lived far above it.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed June 22, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Visions of Penang Archives Online (My Heritage My Penang), accessed June 22, 2013, http://www.visionsofpenang.com.my

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When it was completed in December 1937, the submarine cable between Fukuoka and Pusan became part of the longest carrier telephone line in service. From Fukuoka, the six-channel cable ran over the Japanese mainland to Tokyo, and from Pusan, it extended north through Korea and into the Manchukuo region of China, covering a total of more than 2,000 miles. The cable not only improved the quality of commercial telephone calls between Japan and the continent, but also expanded Japanese military communications in the lead-up to the Second World War.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
Anton A. Huurdeman, The Worldwide History of Telecommunications. Hoboken, NJ: John Wiley & Sons, 2003. 327.
Daqing Yang, Technology of Empire: Telecommunications and Japanese Expansion in Asia, 1883-1945. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2010. 165-9.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Fukuoka has been an exchange point between Japan and the rest of Asia for millennia. In the year 57, a Han Dynasty emperor bestowed a gold seal on the King of Na (present day Fukuoka). Over the following centuries, the city’s proximity to Korea and China facilitated international trade as well as the flow of Buddhism and agricultural techniques into Japan. But this proximity also made it a target: Fukuoka was attacked by Mongol fleets in the 1200s, only to be saved by well-timed typhoons or “Kamikazes” (Japanese for “divine wind”). Communication technologies only reinforced these ancient economic, cultural, and military connections. Telegraph cables linked the Kyushu region with Korea beginning in the 1880s, radiotelephone was introduced in the 1920s, and the arrival of a submarine cable in 1937 provided long-distance telephone service between Japan, Korea, and China for the first time.

The island of Iki, along with its neighbor Tsushima, “form the stepping-stones between Japan and Korea,” explains a 1912 reference book. For centuries, Iki was an intermediate safe harbor for merchant and pirate ships passing through the Genkai Sea. And in the early 1900s, the island became a stepping-stone for cables. By 1920, seven telegraph cables had landed near the southwestern port town of Gōnoura, which sits at the base of an inactive volcano and is surrounded by rice fields. Four of these lines ran to the main Japanese islands and three to Tsushima, where additional cables carried messages the rest of the way to Busan. When a telephone line was installed in 1937, Iki became a stepping-stone for voice signals on their journey across the Korean Strait.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value:
U.S. Hydrographic Office, Asiatic Pilot Volume II: The Japan Islands. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1910.
U.S. Hydrographic Office, Asiatic Pilot Volume II: The Japan Islands (Second Edition). Washington: Government Printing Office, 1920.
Frederick Converse Beach, Ed. The Americana: A Universal Reference Library. New York: Scientific American Compiling Department, 1912.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: If you could climb up the deep green mountains on the northern end of this island, and look west across the water, you would see the hills of the Korean peninsula rising above Pusan. A small island, about 700 square kilometers of land, Tsushima is equidistant between the Japanese mainland and Korea. Because of its location, it had been a trade center for centuries before the cables arrived, and since has been a perfect locale for international cable connections as well as a strategic military node. Five different cables have landed here since 1891. In 1905, during the Russo-Japanese War, a decisive battle was fought in the waters around the island, which the Japanese won largely through their adeptness with wireless telegraphy. Yet this did not lead to the scrapping of “older” cable systems. Quite the opposite. After the war, the Japanese immediately laid a new undersea telegraph cable: wires complement, rather than replace, wireless.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 5, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.

Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1845-1900,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 5, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1850.htm.
Kazuo Hori, “Japanese Government’s Military Demand,” accessed August 5, 2013, https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LLvx96TIJYg2KEzQacVxm7LR-WlVyLbGyNJpxEvb8rM/edit?pli=1.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This Korean city has long been a hub for Japanese connections. In the nineteenth century it was the primary access point for Japanese merchants to Asian trade networks. When it opened, Pusan’s Japanese-run telegraph station became an equally important gateway. It handled all Korean telegraph traffic until an overland link to Seoul was completed in 1888, and it allowed Japanese-language telegrams to leave the country for the first time. Cable traffic spiked from a few thousand messages sent between the two countries in 1884 to some 430,000 — the vast majority were in Japanese. In 1931, Pusan was the site of Japanese experiments for another communications revolution: the use of undersea cables for voice transmission.

Launched in 2010, the Unity cable was the first in nearly ten years to link the U.S. and Japan under the Pacific. As such, it increased capacity along this route by nearly twenty percent. A six-company consortium that includes Google owns the cable, with the Pacnet portion branded as EAC Pacific .

Los Angeles is the only truly urban cable landing on the United States’ west coast. Although it is difficult to string systems into densely populated areas, the more pressing reason for rural cable stations is a legacy of the Cold War. AT&T set up cable stations far from cities in the 1950s and 60s, away from potential targets of nuclear attack. As long as AT&T remained in control, cables stayed at remote stations. But in the 1990s, after the company was broken up, new players in the cable business set up new landings, including this one in the affluent seaside town of Hermosa Beach. From here, cables wind twenty miles inland to a “carrier hotel,” One Wilshire, where it links to hundreds of other networks. One Wilshire, like the cable landing, was also established as a competitor to AT&T. Set up by MCI and Sprint, it was located just three blocks down the road from AT&T’s major switching center. Today it is  one of the country’s most important telecommunications hubs. As Wired Magazine reported, if this building went down “most of California and parts of the rest of the world would not be able to connect to the internet.”

Since the 1880s, Chikura has been known for precision exercises tied to the ocean. Every year, a knife ceremony is held at a local shrine dedicated to the gods of seasoning and culinary arts. Seven or eight men fillet and plate a whole carp using nothing but a twenty-inch blade and a pair of foot-long chopsticks, honoring the town’s legacy as a fishing community. In 1989, Chikura became a site of underwater cable innovation. The first fiber-optic line between the U.S. and Japan landed here, less than fifty miles from central Tokyo, followed by many other cables in the 1990s and 2000s. More recently, the town has become a surfing hub. Several professional competitions are held on Setohama Beach, where well-formed waves crash opposite the prominent cable station.

The KDDI-owned East China Sea Cable, also know as the Japan-China cable system, linked Reihoku and Nanhui in 1976. A commemorative silver coin shows a dotted line across the East China Sea, bisected by a telephone receiver emitting bolts of electricity. Its 480-voice-channel capacity was interrupted in 1980 by fishing operations and not repaired until five years later. ECSC was eventually decommissioned in 1997.

Reihoku occupies a knob-shaped peninsula on the largest island of Amakusa, meaning “heaven’s grass” and named after its verdant, undulating terrain. Part of the underwater network only briefly, the town was linked to Nanhui by the East China Sea telephone cable between 1976 and 1997. Earlier telegraph lines to China surfaced in Nagasaki while Miyazaki received later fiber optic connections. The cable’s landing site is similarly bracketed by historical and contemporary infrastructures. On one side are the ruins of Tomioka Castle, built in the early 1600s by a feudal lord and later attacked by rebelling Christian peasants. And on the other is a modern coal-fired power station that generates most of the electricity for the surrounding Kumamoto Prefecture.

Built in the 1970s, Nanhui station was the first landing site for international coaxial cables in China. Early signals surfaced on the muddy shores of Nanhui district, then mostly farmland, roughly thirty miles southeast of central Shanghai. Now the area is almost unrecognizable, transformed by rapid industrialization that has displaced many of its former inhabitants. Large-scale development projects have even altered the local geography, continuing a process begun millennia ago when Nanhui was formed by silt deposited at the mouth of the Yangtze River. New cables pass by a huge artificial island that contains the recently constructed Shanghai deep-water container port, linked to the mainland by a twenty-mile bridge. And just east of the station, an entire city for 800,000 is being built from scratch on land reclaimed from Hangzhou Bay.

Transpacific Cable-2 established a shortcut across the ocean. While all previous cables across the Northern Pacific had stopped at Midway Island, and sometimes Wake Island, TPC-2 jumped straight from Hawai‘i to Guam, leapfrogging the nodes in between.

A 12th-century sea wall lines the edge of a small village where cables land. Locals come here to take in the panorama, looking east across the ocean. The clear seawater carries you up to white, rocky beaches, abutted by deep green brush leading into steep hills and low forests. The history of this village stretches back hundreds of years, when the sea wall and castle were built, forming the administrative and cultural center of the area. Yet the remoteness of the village made it appealing to cable companies during the coaxial period. After the destruction of World War II, companies surfaced cables far away from urban centers, like Okinawa City, which might be potential targets. In the 1970s and 1980s, a number of important international cables were landed here in Gushikami, making this rural land a submarine communications hub. More recently, the abandoned TPC-2 cable to Guam was revived for geophysical observations rather than telephone calls.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: “International Workshop on the Scientific Use of Submarine Cables,” Past Conferences – International Conferences with EM components, MTNet, accessed August 18, 2013, http://mtnet.dias.ie/conferences/1997/cables97.txt.
Tomishirominami High School Students, “The Sea in Gushikami,” Sea in Okinawa, accessed August 18, 2013, http://www.okiu.ac.jp/Language/contest/01/01/gushikami.htm.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: As you approach Colombo, Ceylon (present-day Sri Lanka) in 1903, your travel guide tells you: “its appearance is extremely picturesque: a fine undulating country, well wooded to the water’s edge and fringed by cocoa-nut trees; lofty verdant ranges tower in the distance, covered with groves of talipat and other palms.” Centrally positioned in the Indian Ocean, Colombo was a key trade port long before the colonial era. In the early 1500s, the Portuguese established a fort and trading post to capitalize on the island’s abundant cinnamon crops. After a brief Dutch occupation, Colombo was ceded to the British and became the capital of British Ceylon. To facilitate faster communication to London, a submarine cable was brought to the island via the Middle East in 1913, connecting to a new Central Telegraph Office in a three-story wood building near the harbor. Messages could now travel between the two cities in as little as thirty minutes, a savings of nearly four hours compared to older land-based routes through India. Today, messages transit in only milliseconds from five cable systems that land in the Colombo area.

Before it was cleared for industrial development in the 1970s, Tuas was a small but active fishing village on the western tip of Singapore. Local fishermen would lay palm fronds on the water’s surface above a submerged net, attracting fish with the shade. The name “Tuas” derives from the Malay word for hauling up the net and the catch it contains. Although this technique is rarely practiced anymore, modern-day Tuas pulls together large-scale networks of various kinds. Global cable systems arrived starting in the late 1990s, connecting to the red and white SingTel station, adorned with a series of porthole-shaped windows and a tall, latticework communications tower. A power plant feeds Singapore’s grid with roughly a fifth of its total supply. Near-constant marine traffic flows through the naval base, shipyards, and container port, while waste is transferred to an offshore landfill. And roadways converge at a checkpoint and mile-long bridge that links Tuas to Johor, Malaysia, offering one of the only terrestrial paths off the island.
In 1917, the 1890 cable across the Tasman Sea was diverted to Titahi Bay In New Zealand and to Bondi Beach in Australia.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The Deep Water Bay cable station is situated on one of the most expensive properties in our undersea network. Overlooking a small bay on Hong Kong’s south shore, the station was built when there was little development in the area. Today, it is the oldest still operational station on the island and has been the connection point for numerous cables since the 1960s. In the intervening years, Hong Kong’s affluent residents migrated to the nearby hills and the area’s forest was replaced with mansions. Unlike the typical windowless structures that populate the cable system, Deep Water Bay’s postwar architecture offers a lookout onto the beaches and ocean below. Peering out of the station windows, you have a better view of the bay than Hong Kong’s richest man. There are few people here to enjoy it, however: since it opened, machines have replaced many of the workers.

Stretching a total of 24,000 miles between 39 landing sites, Southeast Asia-Middle East-Western Europe 3 (SeaMeWe-3) is more than twice as long as its intercontinental predecessor, SeaMeWe-2. The optical cable system was commissioned in 2000 by an international consortium of nearly 100 corporate investors.

For decades, Taiwan’s cables had been concentrated at its northern and southern tips. While the Tanshui and Toucheng stations are on the fringes of Taipei, the Chunghwa Telecom station is located in the rural southern township of Fangshan. Most traffic to Southeast Asia, whether from Taiwan, East Asia, or North America, passes through the Bashi Strait, the narrow passage separating Taiwan and the Philippines. Fangshan was the ideal gateway to this route until recently, when a spate of natural disasters severed numerous cable links. An earthquake in September 1999 broke Taiwan’s terrestrial backbone, one undersea cable, and caused cell sites and radio relays to collapse. The 2006 Hengchun earthquake caused submarine landslides that took out nine undersea links. Most recently,  Typhoon Morakot disrupted six international cables and 1700 wireless base stations, in addition to taking 500 lives. Fangshan, perched on the edge of the Bashi Strait, is no longer a popular interconnection point for undersea traffic.

Although it was originally a swampy wetland, Ancol is now something like the Disneyworld of Indonesia, bustling with rides, beach-goers, and children. Perched on the northern edge of East Java, in Jakarta Bay, it lies in between the upscale waterfront neighborhood of Pantai Mutiara and a busy international ferry terminal. The spot draws visitors from Jakarta and nearby Javanese cities, as well as many who cross the Java and South China Seas, coming to vacation from Sumatra, Singapore, or the Philippines. Cables have trafficked signals into the area since 1859, when an undersea cable connected from a neighborhood just south of Ancol to Singapore and the rest of Asia.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The small fishing village of Budai, Taiwan (known as Hotei in Japanese) played an important role in Japan’s conquest of Taiwan due to its proximity to the Penghu Islands. On the morning of October 10, 1895, Japanese military forces departed from their base on Penghu and sailed to Budai. From there, they moved south to encircle the capital city of Tainan. This connection was retraced more than two decades later by an undersea cable between Budai and Penghu, part of the expansion of Taiwan’s telegraph network under Japanese rule. In addition to its ties to military and communications networks, Budai was a regional hub of salt production in the early twentieth century. The city’s seawater evaporation plant employed several hundred workers and produced roughly eighteen million pounds of salt per year.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Midway between Taiwan and China, this chain of small islands is strategically important. As a result, even though the islands are sparsely populated, they have long been connected by communications networks. In 1887, the government landed a cable here, connecting to China on one side and to the rest of Taiwan on the other. Less than ten years later, the Chinese attacked and attempted to take possession of the islands, but were driven away by the Japanese, who were then occupying Penghu and later, all of Taiwan. The Japanese would remain in Penghu throughout the first half of the twentieth century, laying cables that linked China and Taiwan. While the connected cities grew busy with international trade, the Penghu Islands remained apart from the action, with most ships and signal traffic merely passing through.

http://purl.org/dc/terms/bibliographicCi.value: Bill Glover, “Cable Timeline: 1901-1950,” History of the Atlantic Cable & Undersea Communications: from the first submarine cable of 1850 to the worldwide fiber optic network, accessed August 19, 2013, http://atlantic-cable.com/Cables/CableTimeLine/index1901.htm.
Jonathan Manthorpe, Forbidden Nation: A History of Taiwan (New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 2009), 147.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: Before Hong Kong was handed back to China, one author observed that it was a “center of espionage, a hive of spies,” with up to 5,000 intelligence agents seeking information for countries around the world. In 1977, the British GCHQ built a satellite base at Chung Hom Kok, on Hong Kong’s less populated southern coast. For over a decade, the satellite base, code-named “Project Kittiwake,” was a center for monitoring Chinese communications and nuclear tests. It was reportedly critical for scanning communications about events including the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 and the break-up of the Soviet Union in 1991. When Hong Kong was transferred back to China, Project Kittiwake was moved and the site razed, leaving little for the Chinese to see. At the turn of the century, the Chinese government invested in Chung Hom Kok’s external communications – it was designated a “telecentre” for the development of satellite and submarine connections. Today a new undersea cable station, poised on the edge of a hill and overlooking small fishing boats that dot the waters, still monitors traffic. Rather than intercepting signals sent through the air, communications are now filtered before they are allowed to enter mainland China.

Landing at one of two designated sites on the northern and southern coasts of Changi, you make your way inland to a cluster of stations that form East Singapore’s primary cable hub. Today, the area is known for its major international airport complex, which includes a cactus garden, butterfly habitat, and what will soon be the world’s largest indoor waterfall. But this cutting-edge cable and aviation crossroads has a dark history. The British established a military base at Changi in the early 1900s when the peninsula was still mostly swampland and forests of tall “chengei” trees. During its occupation of Singapore in World War II, Japan used the compound to imprison thousands of captured Allied soldiers. (The prison was rebuilt in the 1990s and now has a death-row detention center.) Even the northern beaches where cables come ashore, a popular spot for picnics and watersports, were the setting for a brutal 1942 massacre of Chinese Singaporeans thought to be anti-Japanese.

EAC-C2C represents the merger of the EAC (East Asia Crossing) and C2C (City-to-City) cable networks, completed in 2007 by Pacnet. Together, they form Asia’s largest privately owned cable system with a total of seventeen landing sites across Japan, Korea, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Singapore.

Madang is fairly small as far as cities go – about 30,000 people live here – but it is the capital and most populous part of its province. The city’s infrastructure is focused outward rather than inward. It is home to many of Papua New Guinea’s export industries, and the landing point for an international fiber-optic cable. The main occupation for many here is a large timber industry, which logs the nearby Gogol forest. In addition, the city exports copra, coconuts, coffee, cocoa, and tobacco, and is home to tuna processing plants and engineering and joinery workshops. The people are also a mix – tourists, missionaries, and contract workers from countries around the world mingle with indigenous people speaking hundreds of different local languages. Papua New Guinea is considered one of the most culturally diverse places in the world, with over 800 different languages spoken by people living mainly in traditional tribal societies. Only a small percentage live in urban, modernized centers like Madang and Port Moresby. But even cities within the country have trouble interacting with each other: the volcanoes that run through the middle of the island have prevented any roads from being built between them.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The PPC-1 cable, laid in 2009 to connect Australia, Guam, and Papua New Guinea, has enough capacity to carry simultaneous phone calls from the entire population of Australia – over twenty million people. Countries don't need to have an extensive network in part due to the enormous capacity of fiber optics.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: The small town of Nasugbu, strategically located on the South China Sea only sixty miles from Metro Manila, is the largest network hub in the Philippines. In the 1990s, the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company opened the country’s first international cable station, which towers over the palm trees and bamboo structures that line the beach. Just down the street is Globe Telecom’s newer facility, an anchor point for the Southeast Asia Japan cable system. Large walls surround both stations and the place where cables enter the water is unmarked. On their journey out to sea, they pass the remains of a Spanish galleon, sunk by the Dutch navy in 1600. Discovered in 1992, the shipwreck became one of the most important finds in underwater archeology. A replica, along with a museum and resort, were built on nearby Fortune Island but have since fallen into disrepair.

The consortium-owned Southeast Asia Japan Cable (SJC) runs from Singapore to Japan, with branch connections to Thailand, Brunei, the Philippines, Hong Kong, and China. Intense demand along the communication route prompted capacity upgrades less than a year after it was built in 2013.

In 1903, the Eastern Extension Australasia and China Telegraph Company was invited by the Dutch East Indies government “to connect Java, Borneo, and Sumatra with the islands of Billiton and Banka [Belitung and Bangka],” notes an issue of The Electrician from that year. “When these cables are established it is expected that they will not only prove a great convenience to the Government and mercantile community, but act as important feeders to the Company’s system” of submarine lines.

The island of Billiton (the old Dutch spelling of Belitung) was a valuable site of tin extraction in the colonial era. Dutch mining operations started in the mid-1800s with the formation of the Billiton Company, named after the island. The company imported thousands of Chinese indentured laborers to perform the heavy and dangerous work in the mines. In the early 1900s, the Dutch East Indies government brought two submarine cables to Billiton’s capital city of Tanjung Pandan, connecting it to colonies in Java, Borneo, and Sumatra. Only a decade later, however, the capital was looted and set ablaze in a worker’s revolt. Belitung and the neighboring island of Bangka are still key points in the global tin trade. The Guardian estimates that in 2012 they produced 90% of the tin in Indonesia, an extraordinary amount given that Indonesia is the second-largest producer of the metal in the world.

Palembang is not on a coast, but about 40 miles inland from the South China Sea, in the south-east corner of Sumatra. But the city has been an important trading and maritime center for millennia due to its location on the Musi River. This wide, grey river runs through the town, dividing the city into halves, and, during the colonial period, easily receiving large military and merchant ships. On one bank, a walled city was built by the Dutch, while the opposite bank remained lined with smaller traditional wooden houses on stilts with deep red roofs. The Musi River both divided and connected – it made it easier for the Dutch East Indies Company to open a trading post here in 1619, and by the 18th century, over 50,000 pounds of spices were exported from the city every year. The telegraph cable, brought in 1859, was used in part to transmit information about this trade. The last section of cable had to be laid using proas, local vessels which snaked 60 miles of cable up the narrow and deep river to its widening at the shores of Palembang.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable was launched on October 19, 1992, with a press conference at the Philippine Plaza Hotel in Manila. It was part of the $320 million ASEAN Optical-Fiber Submarine Cable Network, which also included lines between Brunei and Singapore, and between two parts of Malaysia across the South China Sea.

Cables from Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines surfaced here in the early 1990s, followed by connections reaching as far as the U.S. and Western Europe. A link to the Asia-America Gateway in 2009 created an oversupply of bandwidth, which the Brunei government sold to international carriers in order to finance new cable landings. Located a few miles north of the capital, the station is at once remote and central, surrounded by trees but also a highway exchange and the campuses of both the University of Brunei and an international boarding school. Across the street, a fifteen-story glass office tower (and the second tallest building in the country) contains the headquarters of local telecom provider DataStream Technology Group. When cables arrived on nearby Tungku Beach in the 1990s, illegal sand mining had caused severe erosion. But the jagged shoreline has been restored and is now a popular place for watching sunsets.

Kota Kinabalu is known as KK to many Malaysians and internationals, but locals also call it Api-Api, its original indigenous name, meaning fire. The rapidly growing capital of the eastern Malaysian state, Sabah, is today a culturally, ethnically, and religiously diverse city of half a million people. Many of the country’s banks and insurance companies have their headquarters in tall office buildings clustered at the edge of the sea. From 1964 to 1986, the SEACOM cable connected the city to Singapore, and onward to the global network. This was followed by a fiber-optic link, laid in 1992. KK’s status as an economic and industrial center was prefigured by the British development of its port during the colonial period. The harbor’s connection with the Asian mainland is far more ancient than either the cable or the colony, however. KK is named after nearby Mount Kinabalu, the tallest mountain in the Malay archipelago. Legend has it that Kinabalu is derived from the words for “Chinese Widow.” Long ago, the legend tells, a Chinese prince was shipwrecked in the area and fell in love with a local woman. He returned to China, but promised to come back for her. Every day at sunrise, she would make a pilgrimage to the top of the mountain to look for his ship, until one day she died on the cold summit. The spirit of the mountain turned her face into a rock facing the sea, so that she could always look out towards China.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: When it entered served in 2002, the TGN (Tyco Global Network) cable between Japan and the U.S. offered the highest capacity of any Pacific crossing. Messages travel along this route in a little as .022 seconds. TGN was acquired by the massive Indian company, Tata Communications, in 2005.

http://rdfs.org/sioc/ns#content.value: This cable, laid by the Eastern Extension Australasia & China Telegraph Company, linked down the western side of the Malay peninsula in 1879.

Malacca was an ancient fishing village before it was taken over by the Portuguese in the 1500s, followed by the Dutch and the British. When first telegraph cable arrived in 1879, the port city had both native and colonial populations, and each responded differently to the new technology. According to the British news report from Malacca, the local Malays avoided the cable house after dark, “even now when they see [that] no demon is concealed in the coil of wire.” For Malacca’s European inhabitants, however, the telegraph link was more mundane than mysterious. “One would have thought,” the article laments, “that the laying of the cable would have brought us more into communication with Singapore . . . that the wants of our little Settlement and more news about us would have appeared in the Journals but such is not the case.” Although the settlers did not feel fully connected, the cable had at least one practical benefit: “we get the time more exact than we used to.”
